awd_titl_txt: Study of Magnetically Driven Cylindrical Compression to Create Strongly Coupled Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a new experimental platform combining strong magnetic fields for compression of a metal rod, and a high power laser for high-energy x-ray generation as diagnostics. When a solid material is gradually compressed to high pressures above a million atmospheres, the solid state can be transformed to liquid, gas and eventually plasma. This high density, low temperature state of matter is called a strongly coupled plasma, as found in laser fusion cores and dense astrophysical objects. Modeling of material properties in this regime is challenging because it is too cold and dense to apply ideal plasma theory, but the thermal temperature is too high to be treated with condensed matter physics. Thus, experimental benchmarking of the physics models is important for understanding fundamental properties of high-pressured materials. So far, most compression experiments have been conducted on large laser or pulsed electrical current facilities at national laboratories with limited numbers of shots. Using a cost-effective, university-scale facility, this project will explore the feasibility of magnetically driven cylindrical compression to produce pressures comparable to or even higher than those with a planar compression technique used on large facilities. Laser-produced hard x-rays penetrate through a compressed cylinder, providing information on its density profile and material structure. If successful, the cylindrical compression with a compact pulsed power will allow researchers to study a wide range of materials in the strongly coupled regime for fundamental science and applications. This project will provide full-time support for a graduate student to be trained in relativistic laser-plasma interaction and pulsed power plasma physics.

The goal of this project is twofold: characterization of short-pulse laser-produced hard x-rays and demonstration of x-ray probing of a magnetically compressed millimeter-diameter aluminum rod. Coupled experiments simultaneously using a Mega Ampere (MA) pulsed power and a high power laser in the same vacuum chamber are currently available only at the University of Nevada - Reno Nevada Terawatt Facility (NTF) and at the Z-Machine at Sandia National Laboratory. The experiments will fully utilize the NTF's coupled capability with the 1.0 MA Zebra pulsed power and 50 Terawatt Leopard short-pulse laser. Broadband and monochromatic hard x-rays (> 10 keV) produced in the laser-target interaction will be measured with calibrated x-ray spectrometers and filter stack spectrometers. Compression of a solid Al rod with a diameter ranging from several hundred microns to a few millimeters will be studied with x-ray radiography and x-ray diffraction.

por.por_cntn:
Materials under extremely high pressure exist in the cores of planets, astrophysical objects, and laser fusion capsules. Accurate knowledge of such material properties is critical in numerical modeling. In particular, the near-solid density, low-temperature state of matter, known as strongly coupled matter, is challenging to model because it is too cold and dense to apply the classical plasma theory. However, the thermal temperature is too high to be treated with condensed matter physics. Experimental data are, therefore, crucial for understanding the fundamental properties of highly transient high-pressured materials and benchmarking theoretical and numerical models. 

A slowly rising large current from a pulsed power generator is one of the essential drivers for creating high-density matter among high-power lasers, intense x-ray radiation, and others. The current-driven magnetic pressure is a well-established technique in planar geometry with a huge current only available at large-scale facilities. In contrast, magnetically driven cylindrical compression is an attractive approach for small university-scale facilities to conduct high-pressure experiments because less current is needed than in the planar experiments. However, to diagnose the interior of the compressed matter in the closed system, high-energy photons such as hard x-rays are required. 

This project demonstrated the generation and characterization of hard x-rays using a high-power, short-pulse laser for broadband x-ray radiography of a cylindrically compressed aluminum rod. The experiments were carried out using a Mega Aampere pulsed power generator, Zebra, and a high-intensity, short-pulse laser, Leopard, at the University of Nevada Reno. For broadband x-ray characterization, we conducted laser-only experiments to measure angular-dependent bremsstrahlung radiation and energetic electrons. These measurements were then compared with numerical simulations using a hybrid particle-in-cell code in a 2D and 3D geometry. Direct comparisons of the measurements and simulations enabled the characterization of broadband x-rays and laser-generated energetic electrons. In addition, this project helped develop the laser-pulsed power coupled capability, where the Leopard laser beam was transported into the Zebra pulsed power vacuum chamber to generate hard x-rays. As a result, despite a long beam transport tube and multiple reflection mirrors, broadband hard x-rays were generated in the Zebra chamber, and radiographic images of a cold aluminum rod were obtained. Furthermore, the laser-based broadband x-ray radiography of a complex 3D object (spark plug) was used to develop a numerical modeling technique combining an x-ray spectrum and photon transport calculations with a hybrid particle-in-cell and Monte Carlo codes, respectively.

Results from this project were reported at domestic and international scientific conferences and in five peer-reviewed publications. In addition, two Ph.D. students and several undergraduate students were trained in experimental and/or numerical research projects.
